definition:
Galileo Galilei (1564—1642) has realised the ostensible contradiction in
the situation, that although the set $$1,\,2,\,3,\,4,\,5,\,\ldots$$ of
the positive integers all the members of the set
$$1,\,4,\,9,\,16,\,\ldots$$ of the perfect squares and in many others,
however both sets are equally great in the sense that any member of the
former set has as its square a unique counterpart in the latter set and
also any member of the latter set has as its square root a unique
counterpart in the former set. Galileo explained this by the infinitude
of the sets.

In modern mathematical , we say that an infinite set and its proper
subset set may have the same cardinality.
